segment.source: Interactive logon Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation (Windows 10)
segment.target: Interactive logon Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Interactive logon Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Interactive logon Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation security policy setting.

segment.source: Interactive logon: Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation
segment.target: Interactive logon: Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Interactive logon: Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Interactive logon: Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation security policy setting.

segment.source: Unlocking a locked device requires logon information.
segment.target: Unlocking a locked device requires logon information.

segment.source: For domain accounts, the Interactive logon: Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation policy setting determines whether it is necessary to contact a domain controller to unlock a device.
segment.target: For domain accounts, the Interactive logon: Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation policy setting determines whether it is necessary to contact a domain controller to unlock a device.

segment.source: Enabling this policy setting requires a domain controller to authenticate the domain account that is being used to unlock the device.
segment.target: Enabling this policy setting requires a domain controller to authenticate the domain account that is being used to unlock the device.

segment.source: Disabling this policy setting allows a user to unlock the device without the computer verifying the logon information with a domain controller.
segment.target: Disabling this policy setting allows a user to unlock the device without the computer verifying the logon information with a domain controller.

segment.source: However, if Interactive logon: Number of previous logons to cache (in case domain controller is not available) is set to a value greater than zero, the user's cached credentials will be used to unlock the system.
segment.target: However, if Interactive logon: Number of previous logons to cache (in case domain controller is not available) is set to a value greater than zero, the user's cached credentials will be used to unlock the system.

segment.source: The device caches (locally in memory) the credentials of any users who have been authenticated.
segment.target: The device caches (locally in memory) the credentials of any users who have been authenticated.

segment.source: The device uses these cached credentials to authenticate anyone who attempts to unlock the console.
segment.target: The device uses these cached credentials to authenticate anyone who attempts to unlock the console.

segment.source: When cached credentials are used, any changes that have recently been made to the account (such as user rights assignments, account lockout, or the account being disabled) are not considered or applied after this authentication process.
segment.target: When cached credentials are used, any changes that have recently been made to the account (such as user rights assignments, account lockout, or the account being disabled) are not considered or applied after this authentication process.

segment.source: This means not only that user rights are not updated, but more importantly that disabled accounts are still able to unlock the console of the system.
segment.target: This means not only that user rights are not updated, but more importantly that disabled accounts are still able to unlock the console of the system.

segment.source: It is advisable to set Interactive logon: Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation to Enabled and set Interactive logon: Number of previous logons to cache (in case domain controller is not available) to 0.
segment.target: It is advisable to set Interactive logon: Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation to Enabled and set Interactive logon: Number of previous logons to cache (in case domain controller is not available) to 0.

segment.source: When the console of a device is locked by a user or automatically by a screen saver time-out, the console can only be unlocked if the user is able to re-authenticate to the domain controller.
segment.target: When the console of a device is locked by a user or automatically by a screen saver time-out, the console can only be unlocked if the user is able to re-authenticate to the domain controller.

segment.source: If no domain controller is available, users cannot unlock their devices.
segment.target: If no domain controller is available, users cannot unlock their devices.

segment.source: Set Interactive logon: Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation to Enabled and set Interactive logon: Number of previous logons to cache (in case domain controller is not available) to 0.
segment.target: Set Interactive logon: Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation to Enabled and set Interactive logon: Number of previous logons to cache (in case domain controller is not available) to 0.

segment.source: When the console of a device is locked by a user or automatically by a screen saver time-out, the console can only be unlocked if the user is able to re-authenticate to the domain controller.
segment.target: When the console of a device is locked by a user or automatically by a screen saver time-out, the console can only be unlocked if the user is able to re-authenticate to the domain controller.

segment.source: If no domain controller is available, users cannot unlock their devices.
segment.target: If no domain controller is available, users cannot unlock their devices.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: This policy setting can be configured by using the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) to be distributed through Group Policy Objects (GPOs).
segment.target: This policy setting can be configured by using the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) to be distributed through Group Policy Objects (GPOs).

segment.source: If this policy is not contained in a distributed GPO, this policy can be configured on the local computer by using the Local Security Policy snap-in.
segment.target: If this policy is not contained in a distributed GPO, this policy can be configured on the local computer by using the Local Security Policy snap-in.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: By default, the device caches locally in memory the credentials of any users who are authenticated.
segment.target: By default, the device caches locally in memory the credentials of any users who are authenticated.

segment.source: The device uses these cached credentials to authenticate anyone who attempts to unlock the console.
segment.target: The device uses these cached credentials to authenticate anyone who attempts to unlock the console.

segment.source: When cached credentials are used, any changes that have recently been made to the account—such as user rights assignments, account lockout, or the account being disabled—are not considered or applied after the account is authenticated.
segment.target: When cached credentials are used, any changes that have recently been made to the account—such as user rights assignments, account lockout, or the account being disabled—are not considered or applied after the account is authenticated.

segment.source: User privileges are not updated, and disabled accounts are still able to unlock the console of the device
segment.target: User privileges are not updated, and disabled accounts are still able to unlock the console of the device

segment.source: Configure the Interactive logon: Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation setting to Enabled and configure the Interactive logon: Number of previous logons to cache (in case domain controller is not available) setting to 0.
segment.target: Configure the Interactive logon: Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation setting to Enabled and configure the Interactive logon: Number of previous logons to cache (in case domain controller is not available) setting to 0.

segment.source: When the console on a device is locked by a user or automatically by a screen-saver timeout, the console can be unlocked only if the user can re-authenticate to the domain controller.
segment.target: When the console on a device is locked by a user or automatically by a screen-saver timeout, the console can be unlocked only if the user can re-authenticate to the domain controller.

segment.source: If no domain controller is available, users cannot unlock their workstations.
segment.target: If no domain controller is available, users cannot unlock their workstations.

segment.source: If you configure the Interactive logon: Number of previous logons to cache (in case domain controller is not available) setting to 0, users whose domain controllers are unavailable (such as mobile or remote users) cannot log on.
segment.target: If you configure the Interactive logon: Number of previous logons to cache (in case domain controller is not available) setting to 0, users whose domain controllers are unavailable (such as mobile or remote users) cannot log on.
